title: Who will win the upcoming Philippine presidential election?
preds: Most recent polls had Duterte in the lead, with 33%, Poe 22% and Roxas at 20%. Binay and Santiago were at 13% and 2%, respectively.  I am adjusting my forecast to go with the consensus but I think this is one election that may go against most polls in the final results given the number of voters (55 million), the polarizing, extremist figure that is in the lead (Duterte) and the number of young voters and the number of undecided.
Henceforth, I have decided to avoid giving 100% forecasts when the crowd consensus is quite close by. Not much gain in it and lot of potential for losses.
In the end Trump-style tactics of Duterte are a runaway train.

With the exception of some polls by D'Strafford (more on them in a moment), Duterte has led 10 polls in a row. The average of the last three is as follows: - Duterte: 33%
- Poe: 23%
- Roxas: 21%
- Binay: 15% Binay has fallen off precipitously and is pretty clearly out of serious contention at this point.  Roxas has led two D'Strafford polls, but the outfit seems awfully sketchy (http://www.thinkingpinoy.net/2016/05/tp-investigates-survey-firm-dstrafford.html). Additionally, we can check for favouritism by seeing if the same Liberal Party skew is present in the firm's VP polling. Leni Roberedo, the Liberal VP candidate, scored 32% and 34% in D'Strafford's two most recent polls. The first result is 10% higher than the average of three preceding polls and the latter 8% above the three preceding polls.  My conclusion: D'Strafford's results are garbage and should be ignored. The most recent SWS poll found 10% undecided, but barring a collapse by either supporters of Roxas or Poe toward the other (ideologically similar) candidate, that won't be enough to give the election to anyone other than Duterte.
Poe is doing badly in polling. The "Punisher" will cap everyone's ass to an easy win.

---
Davao City Mayor Rodrigo Duterte keeps his lead over his rivals for the presidency, the latest SWS pre-election survey results revealed Friday, May 6. Duterte maintained a 33% preference rating among 4,500 registered voters nationwide, in the survey conducted May 1-3 – the same period when issues about his alleged hidden wealth came into public consciousness. His rating was unchanged compared to the last SWS survey, which covered April 18-20. Results of these SWS surveys have all been first published on BusinessWorld.
---
http://www.rappler.com/nation/politics/elections/2016/131950-sws-presidential-survey-may-1-3-duterte-leads
Based off most recent polling information.
GP has polled poorly recently. No one can stand up to the "Punisher".
Updating in view of most recent polls: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-election-polls-idUSKCN0XV05A

Roxas is surging but it might be too late to overcome the big lead of Duterte.
http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/05/04/1579719/duterte-maintains-lead-pulse-asia-survey

Duterte up by 10 over Roxas, and 11 over Poe.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-election-polls-idUSKCN0XV05A

---
Davao City Mayor Rodrigo Duterte is still the presidential frontrunner in the latest ABS-CBN survey by Pulse Asia Research. Duterte kept his 33% rating for a 2nd week in a row, in the April 26-29, 2016 survey.
---
http://news.abs-cbn.com/halalan2016/nation/05/03/16/duterte-keeps-lead-in-abs-cbn-survey
Based on views of my co-forecasters

He is far enough in winner take all election, People are desperate enough to vote for someone who is as surreal as the fear that overtakes them. Stock markets are assuming he will win and go down to a low and there is a capital flight as few know how his administration will  effect policy.
The polls are pretty clear about this one now. So it has become a relatively easy call.
I don't have any strong feeling on this one; these are complete guesses.

One week before the election, Rodrigo Duterte is still the top preferred presidential candidate based on the latest survey. The gap also widens between him and the other candidates. It will be harder for the other candidates to catch up.

As an American residing in the Philippines and observing the sentiment of the Filipino people, I can tell you that Duterte is a Trump-like candidate with tremendous appeal for Filipinos, who have endured an Obama-like, do-nothing presidency under NoyNoy Aquino.  The majority of Filipinos are longing for a change and Duterte seems to be the favored candidate.

He likes to hear himself speak and people are listening to his macho speeches to constituents. He is perceived as a strong arm who will raise the Philippines out of a weakened economy, crime, and corruption. If he is successful in duplicating his 'success' in Davao to the country is another story.
He likes to hear himself speak and people are listening to his macho speeches to constituents. If he is successful in duplicating his 'success' in Davo to the country is another story.

---
Davao City Mayor Rodrigo Duterte and Sen. Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr. remained the top picks for president and vice president for the May 9 elections, respectively, based on the latest Pulse Asia survey commissioned by ABS-CBN. Duterte obtained 33 percent voter preference, according to the Pulse Asia poll taken from April 19 to 24, down from 34 percent in its April 12-17 survey.
---
http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/04/30/1578282/duterte-marcos-still-top-picks-pulse-abs-cbn-survey

Updating forecast from Poe 60% - Duterte 30% - Binay 5% - Roxas 5%. Latest polls show Duterte  still in lead even after rape jokes. The 2010 SWS / Pulse Asia polls predicted results fairly accurately and right now is looking a lot like 2010, withe the lead in the mid-high 30s & 2nd place in the low 20s.

Current prez Aquino is making noises about delaying the election by declaring martial law because he is afraid that Duterte and BongBong have "dictatorial tendencies."  Please raise your hand if you believe in the efficacy of defeating dictatorial tendencies by declaring martial law and cancelling elections.  That's what I thought.

A survey, conducted from April 16 to 20, showed Duterte still leading the race with 35 percent of 1,800 registered voters choosing him to be the country’s next president. Duterte’s rating went up by 11 points from 24 percent in the Pulso ng Bayan poll conducted from March 12 to 18. Duterte enjoyed the lead in Metro Manila (40 percent), Mindanao (58 percent) and every socio-economic class (32 percent to 43 percent). The Davao mayor shared the lead with Roxas in the Visayas (32 percent and 27 percent, respectively). In the rest of Luzon, Poe, Binay and Duterte have practically the same voter preferences, 28 percent, 23 percent and 22 percent, respectively.
http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/04/27/1577244/duterte-marcos-widen-lead-pulse-asia-survey
Comment:  Mostly favoring  Duterte
Canadian hostage killing made a splash. Should help the "Law and Order by any means" campaign.

This is now Duterte's to lose - he has been well ahead of Poe in Pulse Asia and SWS polls since early April. Furthermore, it appears that Poe hasn't really been able to break through her 30 point ceiling throughout the entire campaign, whereas Duterte is currently polling around the mid 30s according to the two aforementioned polls [1]. SWS and Pulse Asia have a good track record for predicting the winning candidate in previous elections [2][3].  edit: I should mention that there is a precedent for overcoming a 12 or more point deficit; the May 10 2010 vice presidential election in which Binay overtook Roxas in the span of the final two weeks. As I mentioned above, however, I suspect that Poe's support has hit a ceiling at 30, whereas Binay's numbers were pretty much monotonically increasing during his campaign [4].  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_in_the_Philippine_presidential_election,_2016
[2] http://www.rappler.com/thought-leaders/89126-trust-surveys-opinion-polls
[3] https://dcdabbler.wordpress.com/2016/03/06/on-the-accuracy-of-pre-election-polls-sws-vs-pulse-asia/
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_in_the_Philippine_presidential_election,_2010

Anti-Duterte newspaper coverage has gone nasty and desperate, also a good sign for him.  He'll win, probably, but kakaiba araw ahead for the Philippines.

Consensus favours Rodrigo, and the polling all shows RD in the lead, with Grace as the only contender. Macho mayor Duterte widens gap in Philippine presidency survey
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-election-idUSKCN0XL04E
If misogyny reign in the Philippines, there will be limited effect on Duterte's polls numbers.

There have been two polls released since Duterte's rape comments (http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2016/04/20/roxas-poe-tied-top-spot-d-strafford-poll-468967 & http://interaksyon.com/article/126852/businessworld-sws-april-2016-survey-duterte-leads-despite-rape-joke-leni-bongbong-tied-in-vp) with the average results for the four key candidates looking like this: - Duterte: 26.5
- Poe: 25
- Roxas: 22.5
- Binay: 16.5 The D'Strafford poll runs against virtually every other opinion poll I've seen, giving Roxas a big boost and cutting into Duterte's support. It does, however, also ask voters about how committed they are to their candidate and found that fully one-third of Duterte's voters are open to changing their minds.  I'm torn in how to project this, but I've made the following adjustments:
- Reduced Binay's likelihood to just 2% from 10%. The last two polls show him collapsing, and it would appear his voters are shuffling over to Duterte. I don't feel comfortable writing him off completely as he was just three points back of the lead in a poll from two weeks ago, but it doesn't look good.
- Raised Roxas from 5% to 11%. I don't totally trust the D'Strafford poll because it seems like such an outlier, but I've been expecting voters to migrate from Roxas to Poe and it keeps not happening. He came in at 19% in the SWS survey and has polled between 18% and 26% in all but one poll since the end of January. A good showing in April 24's presidential debate might put him over the top. 
- I have Poe and Duterte in a near-dead heat, at 45% and 42%, respectively. I don't trust Duterte's support to be real - the D'Strafford numbers suggest that it's soft and after three polls topping 30% he's come in below that number in two of the last three. Poe, meanwhile, is holding steady at the same 25-26% support she's been polling at since January. I'm convinced that Duterte is overvalued here; I'm less convinced that Poe can grow her support enough to stop him.

Another couple of polls. I don't know about their provenance, so take with a pinch of salt. http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/local-news/2016/04/20/roxas-poe-tied-top-spot-d-strafford-poll-468967 This one has Roxas ahead. It's an outlier, but I reckon he's undervalued here by a little bit, so I'm putting a couple of points into him. Mostly, however, Duerte is keeping a fairly decent lead, in spite of everything http://interaksyon.com/article/126852/businessworld-sws-april-2016-survey-duterte-leads-despite-rape-joke-leni-bongbong-tied-in-vp

Duterte pulls ahead in the polls as the law & order candidate, despite being widely regarded as at best a jerk and probably a thug (sound familiar?) but Poe has a few days to close the gap.  The folks who are supporting obvious losers are more likely to support her than him, but that's not much to hang a hat on--many will still stay with their faves.

updated for monte carlo analysis of the wiki poll results with more weighting given to the more recent and bigger sample polls, taking account of the standard error of the estimates with 5,000 simulations

I am cautiously optimistic that less than 50% of Filipinos are comfortable with glamorizing rape. Also,  Duterte's threats to cut ties with USA and Australia will certainly be popular among many, but I don't think it will work as well as it might at other times due to the upcoming UNCLOS ruling and China's  continuing Scarborough shoal ventures, both of which are festering Filipino nationalist sentiment. The debate / forces of anti-american bases in Phillipines vs anti China in the S China Sea debate seems to have already played out in favor of the USA, at least at the judicial and legislative levels. Perhaps enough of the public disagree with those decisions to make their voice heard in the election by voting for Duterte, but I think anti-china nationalist sentiment and demonstrated respect for female political leadership in the Philippines limit that probability. 
http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/leading-philippine/2718364.html
There is no second round in the election therefore it is more likely that the leader in the polls will win. It is much more difficult to come from behind in such an election

Might make a difference, but I'm putting him ahead for a while.

Duterte is now leading the polls  http://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-election-poll-idUSKCN0X80CQ http://www.rappler.com/nation/politics/elections/2016/129150-duterte-tops-abs-cbn-poll  He is now leading with 30%, a gain of 6 points, while Grace Poe has dropped to 2nd place with 25% (a drop of 3 points). Binay and Roxas remain statistically tied with 20% and 19% respectively.  We'll have to see if Duterte's outrageous "joke" about an Australian worker who was raped and rutally murdered in the Philippines has any effect.  The matter is getting a lot of international coverage.  http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/17/philippines-presidential-candidate-attacked-over-remarks

I started not knowing the first thing about politics in the Philippines. First I looked at how past elections went. As it turns out, parties in the Philippines are usually short-lived, as alliances form and dissolve. Among the 5 running candidates, we have [1]: * Roxas, Liberal party, social liberalism / center-left, founded in 1946
* Poe, independent, part of the Galing at Puso coalition, center to center-right, founded in 2015
* Duterte, PDP-Laban, left-wing populism / center-left, founded in 1982
* Santiago, PRP, reformism / center-left, founded in 1991
* Binay, UNA, compassionate conservatism / center-right, founded in 2012 Looking through the list of past presidents [2] we get a base rate of 67% for center-right parties and 33% of center-left parties (the latter is all represented by the Liberal party). Social conservatism (in the form of nationalism and Christian right) seems to dominate the center-right scene. I was even getting into what parties formed from the dissolution of which [3] when I decided this was taking too long and decided to look at the polls. Before I did, I had a base rate of 67% for Binay (apparently the only center-right candidate) and 16% each for Santiago and Roxas, since both of them had brushes with the presidency (Roxas is in the incumbent party, Santiago came very close to being elected president in 1992). The polls threw all that out the window [4]. Roxas, Binay and Santiago are all but sure to lose, consistently coming in behind everyone else. Essentially only Poe and Duterte seem to have a shot. With a bit more googling I found that Poe, although independent, is in a center/center-right coaltion. So I decided I would give 5% each to Roxas & Binay, and the remaining 90% I would split between Duterte & Poe according to my center-right/center-left base rate. That gives 2/3 of 90% to Poe (so 60%) and 1/3 of 90% to Duterte (so 30%). I don't feel very confident in these predictions. For all I know, politics in the Philippines might be driven by different dimensions than right/left. But this is what I've got. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_the_Philippines
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_the_Philippines
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_the_Philippines#/media/File:Evolution_of_Philippine_political_parties.png
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_in_the_Philippine_presidential_election,_2016#/media/File:2016_Philippine_presidential_election_polling.svg

Based on his past history as a Filipino lawyer and politician I believe Rodrigo Duterte will win the upcoming Philippine presidential election. He has a reputation for being incredibly blunt, and has shown that he is capable of transforming cities from areas with high murder rates to tourist attractions. I believe this is enough to gain him favor from the people and allow him to win the presidential election.

upping Duterte again after recent polling edit: once again, I beg people not to let their emotions affect their forecasting on elections. Sure, Duterte is a womanizing murderous strongman, whereas Poe is a nice American-educated lady with a cool life story & sensible politics. I know who we'd all vote for. But just like Trump, that doesn't mean Duterte can't win, especially in an election in which he only needs to win a simple plurality
The momentum of Rodrigo Duterte will be affected by his joke about rape. Because of this, Grace Poe might take the lead again. Whatever the result of this election, this will be a close fight.
Im no analysis, but this feels right.

Pulling Duterte down a little, due to his remarks which may alienate the women's vote..

Duterte is now leading in the polls, so Binay and Roxas are going after him harder than before.  Roxas has been the favourite of current prez Aquino, but Roxas isn’t moving much in the polls, so the Palace seems to be leaning toward Plan B, which is Poe.  Elections in the Philippines are generally cleaner than you probably suppose, but not exempt from the occasional shenanigan, so an Aquino-Poe alliance may figure out some clever tricks to improve her odds.  (On the bright side, election-related killings are down a lot over the past couple of decades.) http://thephilippinestar.ph/articles/2016-04-13/news/duterte-bongbong-pull-away-in-pulse/147497

http://www.mb.com.ph/roxas-tells-duterte-dont-mislead-us/ In an unrelated story, the Philippines seems likely to have a vice president called BongBong, who is the Marcos kid.  I don’t care much for the Marcos family, but am in no position to say anything about his nickname—I once voted in cold blood for a gubernatorial candidate called Bubba, in Louisiana in 1979.  Oddly, perhaps, he was universally regarded as the good-government candidate. This being Louisiana, that tag doomed him to finish fifth out of six.

Duterte continues to pull ahead in the polls.  Binay may have a better election-day ground game, but by then it may not matter.  Probably too early to count Poe out also.  http://www.manilatimes.net/duterte-marcos-also-top-pulse-poll/255732/

Election rule: candidate with the most votes is elected, 50% of vote is not required.
Forecast is based on recent wiki polling info.  Not sure that the polls are reflective of the actual vote, since all of the candidates range from the upper 20% mark (Poe) and the lower 20% mark (Roxas). It seems that, without a second round, the voters may abandon the lower performing candidates as Election Day approaches.  
Have not researched who may gain from voter consolidation in the last few days.
Duterte doing well in some of the more recent polls, though Poe still in lead

What is probably the last court pronouncement once again clears Poe to stand for prez.  She is still ahead by various margins in any polls that aren't run by declared or otherwise obvious opponents of hers.  Still, one never knows.  It is very likely that Binay has a better organized election-day ground game in case turnout is important.

So little data, so little time! The recent poll quoted by a top comment had a wide margin of error, but it is information and it deserves to be noted. Grace Poe seems like a frontrunner, and there's not much time for her to come crashing down. Shot-in-the-dark guess here, more probability for Poe but less optimism than many others about her.
consensus seems more bullish on Poe that polling data would indicate

Poe's support appears to have hit a ceiling (30%) at the end of 2015 and then has stabilised just below that level for this election. On the contrary, Duterte's vote share can be volatile at times with huge spikes coming in, but on the whole, it is still clearly moving up on a trajectory that could take him to victory.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_in_the_Philippine_presidential_election,_2016 Am also discounting Binay as a potential winner (lost huge vote share in the election build up) and tilting this in Duterte's direction.  This call is probably a bit premature, but I am taking a break from this site for a few weeks and may not be back before this election is over. So can't help but take a position on this.
New polls put Duterte far ahead of Poe and the rest, and there's no runoff (i.e. most votes wins): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_in_the_Philippine_presidential_election,_2016

Major revision. Dropping Poe from 90% to 45%. Latest polls show Duterte has caught up with Poe. Right now it's a tie. If new polls show someone with a 3%+ lead, I will tilt that way. Till then this is hard to call. Duterte is being referred to as Philippine's 'Trump' based on his style of campaigning. Clearly, if personality is important in presidential elections, Poe has some competition.

The Manila Times, which is consistently anti-Poe, points out that Binay and Roxas have machines and nobody else does, and machines work:
http://www.manilatimes.net/only-binay-and-roxas-have-electoral-machinery/253878/ On the other hand, at least one machine in Cebu came out for Duterte:
http://www.mb.com.ph/one-cebu-backs-duterte-for-president-promises-1m-votes/ And Poe is kissing up to the very powerful Iglesia ni Cristo machine, which works well with Estrada who is backing her:

This is one of those times when a 13-hour time difference is sort of a drag.  Current betting around town is that the Court will kick her out on residency and not rule on citizenship at the moment, since it doesn’t matter this year if she loses on residency. 
http://www.mb.com.ph/sc-to-vote-on-poes-disqualification-cases-on-wednesday/ The Cojuangcos are a long-time political power. Danding will probably wait until the Court says something, but one of the clan has already come out for Binay, and there is some suspicion that at least one other senior guy in the party is a Duterte fan.  The official party hierarchs have come out for Poe. The NPC is looking more and more like the US Republicans all the time, but party affiliation has usually been more ephemeral in the Philippines.

Defensor-Santiago has been struggling to crack four percent in the polls for months now; it would seem she can be dismissed. 
The remain four candidates are closely grouped. If we take an average of the last four polls released on the election, we find Poe leading the way with 27%, Binay in second at 25%, Duterte in third at 23% and Roxas in fourth at 20%, with all of them within striking distance of each other. 
The key item now is Poe's eligibility to run, currently before the Supreme Court. I don't have any insight into how the court will rule, but I do note that six of the 15 judges were appointed by political ally (and current president) Benigno Aquino, while the other nine were appointed by Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, who defeated Poe's father in the 2004 presidential election. 
I'm guessing here that it's 60/40 they rule Poe ineligible, strictly on that split. If she is eligible I'd give here a 30% chance of winning (a slight plurality) so assuming my 60/40 split is somewhere in the ballpark of reasonable that leaves her 12%.
Where do her votes go if she's deemed ineligible? My guess from an hour or so of reading is primarily to Roxas. Both are allies of Aquino; Poe ran as an independent but as part of his Team PNoy in the 2013 senatorial elections and Roxas aggressively courted her to be his running mate as VP in this election. That likely migration is enough to boost Roxas' totals for me.
Binay arguably has the value of incumbency in that he's the current Vice President (though he narrowly beat Roxas, who was affiliated with Aquino and has been endorsed by him), and his polling numbers seem to have stabilized after a steep fall from mid-2014 to mid-2015. Two of the last six vice presidents have gone on to the presidency, though the numbers increase to 2-of-3 if we disregard those who chose not to run. 
Duterte can't entirely be ruled out, but he's been vocally opposed to Poe's eligibility and its hard to imagine her support swinging his way if she's deemed ineligible.

The latest poll shows that Binay is on a downward trend. Maybe it was affected by the debates. But I still give Binay an edge over Poe since the pending is a bit of a problem for Poe. Overall, this presidential race is very close and the polls may still change in the coming weeks.

Still guessing that the Supremes will bar Poe for residency, leaving Binay and Duterte.  Too early yet to feel real secure about a result, but Binay looks good at the moment. In Roxas news, his gang are intermittently optimistic, but at least one commentator thinks there's not much reason to be.

I know virtually nothing about Philippine politics, so this will be an interesting exercise for me.
Polling suggests there are only a small number of undecideds.  A fifth candidate is polling very poorly, so I am excluding them completely. There are four leading candidates, so baseline for each is 25%. 
The race is tight between the four, polling has seen substantial changes, the official campaign has only recently begun and the final list of candidates was only finalised at the end of January 2016.  
Roxas has seen his poll numbers steadily improve, but has not yet broken through the pack and has to still be considered fourth.  However, this could change over the course of the campaign.
Duterte, with the exception of one short lived peak in Dec 2015, has polled similarly to Roxas.  It will be interesting to see if he can maintain momentum and gain traction across the country.
Binay started out as the clear favourite in polling in 2014, but as the menu of candidates has become clearer his lead has fallen and then evaporated.  However, his polling numbers have not dipped below 20%, suggesting a substantial core support base.
Poe is the current leader in averaged polls and has seen support rise over time and has not been below 20% since before mid-2015.
Sources: 
http://thediplomat.com/2016/01/7-things-to-know-about-the-2016-philippine-elections/
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippine_presidential_election,_2016
http://www.ibtimes.com/philippine-presidential-election-binay-poe-keep-lead-latest-poll-2307102

The Supreme Court of the Philippines is set to make a decision on Grace Poe's qualification on March 8.  Apparently the justice in charge of the case submitted a draft decision, but the other judges asked for more time to come up with respective concurring or dissenting opinions. The draft submitted by the justice in charge of the case is said to UPHOLD COMELEC'S DECICION DISQUALIFYING POE FOR MATERIAL REPRESENTATION IN HER CERTIFICATE OF CANDIDACY by claiming she had met the 10-year residency requirement before the May 9 elections.  The draft is also said to have been "silent on the issue of eligibility of Poe as a natural-born citizen for being a foundling." Some of the justices are expected to disagree with the drafted opinion "on the belief that the senator is eligible for the presidency and would meet the required residency" by May 9.   The justices have not deliberated on the draft ruling yet but rumors abound that they have already voted 9-6 or 8-7 IN FAVOR OF POE.  The tone used by Poe herself regarding the issue may be telling. She said that she had heard different versions of the court's ruling but that "nothing was final." The COMELEC disqualification of POE was based on the notion she was not a "natural-born citizen as a foundling and had not met the 10-year residency requirement."  They cited that her "intention to stay in the country for good was absent since she decided to keep her US citizenship and continued to use her US passport until 2010" after returning to the Philippines in 2005.  Apparently Poe reacquired her residency in the country on Aug. 31, 2006, which, COMELEC says would meant that her residency eligibility would still fall short by about three months.   As noted in one the articles linked below, the question of "citizenship merely involves legal interpretation while residency is factual or based on facts and evidence."   I'm lowering POE's odds based on my thinking that unless there's a strong political influence in the court, she may be disqualified from running until the next election. She was allowed to run for the Senate  Sources: http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/770351/dq-of-grace-poe-wont-be-a-surprise
http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/03/02/1558659/sc-votes-poe-dq-tuesday In another interesting news, president Aquino this week attacked BINAY's campaign saying that his running mate, the senator Gringo Honasan, was behind a series of coup attempts during his mother, Corazon Aquino's admin in the late 1990's. Aquino acknowledge that BINAY had fought for democracy during those coup attempts but that his chosen running mate was the one who had planned the overthrow.  Not sure how this affects BINAY since people vote separately for president and vice president... The same article makes mention of "mass deflections" from ROXAS camp to BINAY and POE and cited "lagging in the polls"  Adjusting forecast to reflect this.  http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/03/04/1559263/noy-stumps-roxas-hits-binay

Keeping the same numbers for now, but adding comment. It appears Binay is the preferred candidate by China. This may add a new dynamic to the voting if Philippine voters feel that a candidate is too close to China......who has caused all sorts of havoc in the South china sea and other pressures against the Philippines.  Reference (and there are others): http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-buzz/will-philippine-elections-bring-about-new-china-policy-15288?page=2 "When one presidential candidate, Jejomar Binay, openly suggested the prospect of joint development in South China Sea, he immediately provoked a firestorm of criticisms. Neither the currently-leading presidential candidate, Senator Grace Poe, nor Aquino’s anointed successor, Interior Secretary Mar Roxas, have, so far, dared to suggest a similar approach, probably out of fear of political backlash. Secondly, unlike the Arroyo administration, the Philippines is grappling with an acute crisis in the South China Sea, with Beijing establishing a sprawling network of dual-purposes bases and airstrips across both Paracels and Spratly chain of islands. There is a genuine fear that soon China will establish a military base in the Scarborough Shoal and/or start cutting off Filipino supply lines in the disputed waters."

Philippine election rules award the presidency to the top vote-getter; there is no run-off or second round voting. Polls have consistently shown Poe and Binay in the top two slots, trading places over the short electoral campaign season. Poe's father narrowly lost the presidential election himself in a prior year, suggesting that she may be poised to pick up his support. Binay has been polling above her however; yet the race continues to be in flux due to legal challenges to her candidacy. C- comparison to previous Philippine elections, H- changing polling results, W- wildcards such as constitutional/legal challenges to Poe's candidacy could shift the race.

http://www.mb.com.ph/poe-extremely-grateful-for-npc-endorsement/
http://www.mb.com.ph/poe-camp-takes-swipe-against-lp-for-questioning-npc-endorsement/
http://www.manilatimes.net/poe-chiz-to-invade-cagayan-valley/247476/ Poe is likely to win if she's not kicked out for residency/citizenship. Important endorsement, probably, and largish rallies in Leyte down in the Visayas, and probably at Tuguegarao in northern Luzon.  However: http://thephilippinestar.ph/articles/2016-02-29/news/sc-to-deliberate-separately-on-poe-citizenship-residency/142119 There is some betting that she'll win on citizenship but lose on residency.  Meantime: http://thephilippinestar.ph/articles/2016-02-29/news/miriam-still-campus-favorite/142111 Defensor-Santiago popular with the kids, says if enough people vote for her, she'll win.  An unarguable proposition, but with no particular predictive value.  Punchline is no reason to change numbers until the Supreme Court rules on Poe.

Latest polls put Poe and Binay near the top, and suggest that D-S has little chance. Im assuming that Binay gets a boost when people go to vote on the basis of his experience, whereas Poe's support will drop a bit as people have second thoughts about her celebrity and lesser experience and move towards establishment figures. Overall assumption is that polls will translate pretty well into final result though.

Binay has a scandal on his hands, since  he just admitted he owns a ranch that was listed as owned by his aide. That puts him in second, but not by much since scandal is not a guarantee of failure. It edges Duterte and Mar Roxas, since if Binay falls, they can fight for his spot. MDS is not a likely shot, nor is an unknown. I will adjust them down as time goes on and nothing Black Swan-ish happens. Poe is polling at 30 percent, but her citizenship status is in question. I will adjust as more news becomes available.

This was DUTERTE at the debate on Sunday:  "If I become president, it would be bloody"  He said he would take down criminals, drug traffickers and corrupt officials in six months if elected.  Duterte also said that HE HAS KILLED AN UNSPECIFIED NUMBER OF CRIMINALS HIMSELF but did not provide details.  He has said that he would reinstate the death penalty but that he WOULD NOT RESORT TO EXTRA JUDICIAL KILLINGS (something he has been criticized for as mayor of Davao.)  He also addressed issues regarding extra marital affairs and accusations of being a womanizer.  Mar Roxas, the candidate endorsed by the current president and the party in power, pledged to continue the battle against poverty and corruption.  Under Aquino, the economy has improved. More than 2 million people are said to have been lifted out of poverty.   Jejomar Binay, the current VP, said he would govern as he has as mayor of Makati, the country's main financial district.  He defended himself against accusations of massive corruption, which put him under a Senate committee investigation for months. Grace Poe showcased her work in the senate including pushing a larger budget to help poor farmers and a freedom of information bill that failed to pass. She said her being a newbie shouldn't be an issue in a country where longtime politicians have failed to ease basic problems like hunger. Miriam Defensor-Santiago, said she would crack down on corruption like she has done in her long government career, including as a feisty former trial court judge. http://news.yahoo.com/philippine-elections-debate-aims-shift-star-struck-voters-093844239.html Polls have not been released.  Duterte sounds too crazy.  So far, seems like Grace Poe and Mar Roxas are the most viable candidates.

Sex of presidents were mostly male, governors of top 10 vote rich provinces were mostly male, Political parties of liberal and Nacionalista tied in second place for Philippine presidents elected(13) Other political parties lumped together are at the top with minimal leverage to the two and independent none. Candidates having corrupt issue or poor performance than those who have none. Experience on execution is puts more weight in decision making of Filipinos than those had none.

Spoke to a person in the Philippines today who said Mar Roxas is now leading the polls after the first debate took place yesterday, Feb. 21.  
The first presidential debate to be held in the country in 24 years was a big event there and was meant to focus the race on policy and not on the cult of personality which has tended to dominate elections. The person I talked to, a 19 year old college student, said most young college students are backing Miriam Santiago. She has a good reputation and back record.  I asked her about Santiago being diagnosed with cancer and she said it was just a rumor and that the cancer had not come back.  She said a lot of people like Grace Poe because of her famous parents and also because her father also ran for president but that after the debate, she doesn't think she will remain the top contender.   Official polls following the debate are not out yet but are expected this week.  As for social media, the debate was a world trending topic on Twitter and Duterte generated the most buzz, followed by Binay and Roxas.   I'

A mix of polling data and some adjustments for the consensus so far. Plus some skimming of news stories on the candidates -- reading the exact language sources that favor candidates use for them is often helpful.  The young internet users of the Philippines LOVE Duterte -- or at least the English-speakers do. Binay's been around forever, has picked up average-sounding political accomplishments, but doesn't seem like the enthusiastic choice for most groups. If Duterte gets younger people and Binay older people, not sure where that leaves Poe. I'll leave the three of them as basically even for now.

Jejomar Binay is still leading the polls even with allegations of corruption. However, Duterte and Poe is catching up. I give a slight advantage to Duterte over Poe because of the pending disqualification case of Poe which adds doubt to the voters.

Last I heard, Poe's eligibility was up in the air.  However, if that's sorted in her favour, she probably wins.  VP Binay is the resume candidate and more or less heir presumptive, but one notes that Pres Aquino has declined an endorsement.  He seems to be Hillary Clinton--even his supporters don't really like him.  Poe is largely independent, but not a Trump/Sanders barnburner. The rest of the field look like regional or niche candidates at best.  Still waiting to hear from more actual Filipinos, since iI haven't lived there in over 50 years--when I left, Bongbong Marcos' daddy had just been elected president of the Senate and his mom's shoe collection was barely worth mentioning.

This is one entangled process.  No wonder this is the question with the least forecasts.  But Philippines is a big country, counted as an American ally, and a major player in the South China sea disputes so it's good to pay attention.  Will save you the details on the electoral system and political ladder bits.  Here are the most recent poll by Social Weather Stations, as of Feb. 13, 2016, and some info on top candidate's backgrounds: POE  27.0% - 
Running as an independent. But she's the daughter of two of the famous actors in the country.  And the cult of personality runs very far here. Her personal story is also huge, she was abandoned in a church at birth and later adopted by her famous parents. She's been challenged and even sued regarding residency qualifications.  She had resigned her Philippino citizenship to live in the US, and regained it in 2005.  She was head of the Movie and TV Classification Board and also a senator since 2013. She has a degree from Boston College and lived much of her adult life in Fairfax, Virginia. DUTERTE 26.4% -
Lawyer, has been mayor of a major city for 7 terms, Davao, which has consistently ranked among the top 10 safest cities in the world (4th in 2015).  He has been criticized by human rights groups for supporting extra judicial killings of alleged criminals by vigilante groups.  BINAY 21.4% - 
Former human rights lawyer, helped fight Marcos as an activist 30 years ago. He became the mayor of the country's version of Wall St. and served as VP in 2010. He's popular but is tainted with accusations of corruption which is affecting him in the polls.  ROXAS 19.0% - 
Endorsed by Aquino, the current president. Held influential posts in government, has access to power as the ruling party's candidate. He was an investment banker, and has been credited with making the Philippines one of the world's top job outsourcing destinations.   DEFENSOR 3.9% -
 Popular senator who has run for president 3 times before.  She is said to be suffering from a stage 4 cancer.  The first debate is scheduled for Feb. 21. Will monitor changes then.
Grace Poe is favourite to win provided she does not get disqualified thus the hedge with the next most likely candidate, Binay.

wild guess just based on polls https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_in_the_Philippine_presidential_election,_2016#Single-choice_surveys

Based exclusively on the polls between 27-Nov 2015 and 4-Feb 2016 (found here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_in_the_Philippine_presidential_election,_2016#Single-choice_surveys ) I made the average of the poll results (Nate Silver style!) and its standard deviation for the four top candidates (JB, RD, GP and MR). Don't be afraid it can be done easily in 10 minutes on MS Excel. Here are the results: JB   26,71 +/- 4.35
RD 20,86 +/- 1.86
GP 26.00 +/- 3.21
MR 20.86 +/- 1.47 According only to those numbers  I would say that RD and MR are getting behind... So I am putting their probablity a lot lower the BJ's and GP's: MR and BJ have 10% both.  The real decision will be between JB and GP. Unfortunately it is too close to call based solely on the polls.  But I am assigning a small advantage to JB because he is the incumbent vice-president (and as such has more air-time on the media and better access to government means), This advantage is very slim, though: no more than 4%.  This is one of those forecasts that I expect  to be revised a LOT so it is important to state the conditions on which they can be altered: - since i am basing my forecast on poll aggregation I think  that new polls getting made are a factor. - some special event (hurricane, floods, earthquake) that would influence clearly the election on behalf of the incumbent VP (JB) as they provide more media opportunities for government officials (which can be critical on a very tight race like this).

I know absolutely nothing about Philippine politics so anything I say could be wrong. This forecast is based on polls plus a handful of articles. Ignoring the prediction markets. -Leaning slightly in favor of the charismatic candidate (Duterte). These types often do better than their polling suggests. On the other hand, "analysts say his campaign will falter because he lacks a strong national organization and funding" (see IBT below). "Analyst" predictions should be taken with a grain of salt.
-Not ruling out Roxas, who is leader of the ruling party. That should give him some advantages, right?
-Binay, the opposition coalition leader, evidently has an effective ground game. But, being tainted with corruption when an anti-corruption candidate is doing so well makes me bearish about his chances.
-Poe has polled consistently well and seems to be an appealing candidate with successes in electoral and legislative politics. She also seems to have overcome her citizenship issues in the court of public opinion. It's still a very close race (i.e., within the margin of error) between the top 4 candidates. Critiques of my analysis are welcome. Background: http://thediplomat.com/2016/01/7-things-to-know-about-the-2016-philippine-elections/ & http://www.ibtimes.com/philippine-presidential-election-binay-poe-keep-lead-latest-poll-2307102
Based exclusively on polls, for now know nothing else: http://www.bworldonline.com/content.php?section=TopStory&title=binay-slips-duterte-up-in-sws-survey&id=123064
